docs.lead_paragraph: Spending on prescription drugs increased a record 17.4 percent last year, and elderly people experienced the largest cost increases, a new study by a drug benefits company said. The study, released today by Express Scripts of St. Louis, said about half of the total increase in drug spending was a result of higher costs for a typical prescription.

headline.main: 17 Percent Increase in Prescription Drug Costs Hit Elderly Hardest, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study released by Express Scripts of St Louis, drug benefits company, finds spending on prescription drugs increased record 17.4 percent in 1999 and that elderly people experienced largest cost increases; its findings detailed (M)
docs.snippet: Spending on prescription drugs increased a record 17.4 percent last year, and elderly people experienced the largest cost increases, a new study by a drug benefits company said.     The study, released today by Express Scripts of St. Louis, said...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Ways and Means Committee passed legislation last week that promises to provide Medicare enrollees with coverage of prescription drugs. The promise might serve Republicans well as an election-year inoculation against Democratic sniping over lack of drug coverage. But the bill would not serve the elderly well. A better plan was offered later in the week by Democrats in the Senate. Their bill was swatted away by Republicans in part because it was sprung on them by surprise. Neither vote helped the elderly get what they need, adequate drug coverage. President Clinton tried to turn matters around Saturday, calling for coverage about twice as expensive as the plan he had previously proposed and the plan the House committee passed. Mr. Clinton's revised coverage mirrors that of the Democratic bill in the Senate.

headline.main: A Middle Ground on Medicare Drugs

docs.abstract: Editorial praises plan offered by Democratic Sen Bob Graham, covering insurance payments for drugs under Medicare, as better than Republican proposal, which would not serve elderly well; criticizes Democrats for not doing more to forge bipartisan support for legislation, which was quickly dismissed by Republicans; says bill could have been crucial middle ground between Republican proposals that rely almost entirely on private plans and some Democratic proposals that embrace little competition (M)
docs.snippet: The House Ways and Means Committee passed legislation last week that promises to provide Medicare enrollees with coverage of prescription drugs. The promise might serve Republicans well as an election-year inoculation against Democratic sniping over...

docs.lead_paragraph: Freshly stung by their 1998 election losses, House Republicans vowed one thing as the reality of their defeat sunk in: they would learn from their mistakes. In no time, the speaker was ousted and another took the helm. The new strategy was relatively simple: the Republicans would deflect the label of a ''do nothing Congress'' and satisfy their core voters by passing small tax cuts -- the same bills President Clinton vetoed as part of a giant package last year.

headline.main: House Republicans Fret About 'Do Nothing' Tag

docs.abstract: House Republicans approach Fourth of July recess with sense of foreboding on number of sensitive issues, most trumpeted by Democrats, that could undermine their strategy and possibly hurt them in Fall 2000 elections; some major pending issues discussed (Political Memo)(M)
docs.snippet: Freshly stung by their 1998 election losses, House Republicans vowed one thing as the reality of their defeat sunk in: they would learn from their mistakes.    In no time, the speaker was ousted and another took the helm. The new  strategy was...

docs.lead_paragraph: The struggle over prescription drug benefits for the elderly, now center stage in the House, is not simply between Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives. It has also driven a wedge between two of the biggest, most influential lobbies in Washington: the Health Insurance Association of America and the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America. For months now, the pharmaceutical industry has been arguing -- on Capitol Hill and beyond, in an intensive advertising campaign -- that any new prescription drug benefit for the elderly must be provided through the private sector, not the traditional Medicare program.

headline.main: Fight Over Prescription Drug Benefits for Elderly Creates Unlikely Enemies

docs.abstract: Struggle over prescription drug benefits for elderly has driven wedge between two of biggest, most influential lobbies in Washington: Health Insurance Assn of America and Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America; pharmaceutical industry argues that any new prescription drug benefit for elderly must be provided through private sector, not traditional Medicare program; industry said to fear that direct government involvement will lead to government pressure on drug industry prices; insurance industry is warning that private-sector solution would be difficult to achieve, and that even with federal subsidies, private companies would have hard time offering affordable product and making profit in market where drug prices keep rising and sickest elderly people are most likley to buy the coverage (M)
docs.snippet: The struggle over prescription drug benefits for the elderly, now center stage in the House, is not simply between Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives. It has also driven a wedge between two of the biggest, most influential lobbies...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Health care rationing has been around for a long time (Week in Review, June 18). Not everyone can go to the ''best'' hospital or doctor.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Matz letter responds to June 18 Week in Review article on health-care rationing; asserts question is not whether to ration health care, but rather who will determine ground rules for rationing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Health care rationing has been around for a long time (Week in Review, June 18). Not everyone can go to the ''best'' hospital or doctor.

docs.lead_paragraph: SUSAN HOROWITZ faced the classic patient's dilemma. Three different doctors had given her three different recommendations about whether to undergo chemotherapy for her breast cancer. ''I found the idea of chemo really frightening,'' she recalled. Chemotherapy, she knew, would throw her into menopause - and she was only 45 years old.

headline.main: The Big Decisions? They're All Yours

docs.abstract: *Women are becoming increasingly familiar with challenge, and agony, of medical decision making; revolution in patients' rights and explosion of information on Internet and elsewhere is enabling women to educate themselves as never before; doctors' attitudes have changed as well; once derided for their paternalism, many now expect patients to research their own diseases and make decisions on their own; studies show that women are gatekeepers of family health, making decisions not only for themselves, but also for their spouses, children and parents; photos (M)
docs.snippet: SUSAN HOROWITZ faced the classic patient's dilemma. Three different doctors had given her three different recommendations about whether to undergo chemotherapy for her breast cancer. ''I found the idea of chemo really frightening,'' she recalled....

docs.lead_paragraph: ETHELYN BOWERS had a master's degree, an executive-level job and a husband who was a doctor with access to some of the best medical care available. But her accomplishments and connections seemed to make little difference when she endured the premature births and subsequent deaths of three babies, two of whom were in a set of triplets. A competitive businesswoman who is immersed in her career and the hectic schedules of her surviving children, now 9 and 11, Ms. Bowers is candid about her losses but does not dwell on their possible causes. ''I just chalked it up to bad luck, mainly,'' said Ms. Bowers, a sales director for Lucent Technologies who lives with her family in Livingston, N.J.

headline.main: A Racial Gap in Infant Deaths, and a Search for Reasons

docs.abstract: Growing field of research is struggling to explain a persistent racial gap in US infant mortality rates; even as overall rate improves, to a record low national average of 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births, the disparity between whites and blacks has grown, from 2 to nearly 2.4 times the number of infant deaths; especially troubling is evidence that this is not simply because of poverty; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for the last decade, yet theranks of the uninsured keep growing. Having risen by more than a million a year in the 1990's, the number of uninsured now stands at 44.3 million - 16 percent of the population - even though the United States is enjoying the longest period of economic growth in its history.

headline.main: Still Uninsured, and Still a Campaign Issue

docs.abstract: Problem of Americans who lack health insurance has been debated endlessly for decade, yet ranks of the uninsured keep growing, now standing at 44.3 million, or 16 percent of population; Clinton administration tried and failed to solve problem with sweeping health care initiative in 1993-94, and issue promises to loom large in this year's presidential campaign; several reasons why reform defies best efforts of policymakers detailed; initiatives of Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush, and their potential pitfalls, described; charts profile the uninsured (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OF all the zingers uttered by my obstetrician, Alan DeCherney (known for his great delivery, in every sense of the word), the most memorable was when I told him that I thought I wanted to squat while giving birth. ''And what am I supposed to do?'' he demanded. ''Get down on the floor in a raincoat?'' The year was 1987. The hospital was Yale-New Haven. Note that I said hospital. As an elderly primagravida (loosely translated, a first-time mom-to-be who will be receiving mail from the AARP by the time her child is in middle school), my concern was not so much to experience childbirth as to survive it.

headline.main: The Baby and the Bathwater: Birth Methods Then and Now

docs.abstract: Elin Schoen Brockman article on trends in birthing methods, from natural childbirth and water immersion to booking inductions and Caesarians months ahead of time; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Two basic standards in journalism were ignored in the story on the Bedford schools' budget battles. Unfounded allegations of bigotry were published without a source or evidence. Secondly, no one, myself included, who opposed the $65.7 million budget was contacted.

headline.main: Bedford Budget Opponents Cite Financial Mishandling

docs.abstract: Philip Christe letter holds June 18 article on fight over school budget in Bedford, NY, contained unfounded allegations of bigotry; editor's note: budget has been approved (S)
